# A.18. Containers

:::danger
This Reference Manual output has not been verified,
and may contain omissions or errors.
Report any problems on the [tracking issue](https://github.com/ada-lang-io/ada-lang-io/issues/20)

import Admonition from "@theme/Admonition";
import AnnotatedOnly from "@site/src/components/AnnotatedOnly";
import CodeBlock from "@theme/CodeBlock";
import MarginText from "@site/src/components/MarginText";
import MarginInfo from "@site/src/components/MarginInfo";

<MarginText>1/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>This clause presents the specifications of the package Containers and several child packages, which provide facilities for storing collections of elements.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>1.a/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<b>Term entry: </b><b>container</b> &mdash; structured object that represents a collection of elements all of the same (potentially class-wide) type, such as a vector or a tree<br />Note: Several predefined container types are provided by the children of package Ada.Containers (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.1">A.18.1</a>).<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI12-0196-1", "AI12-0416-1"]} />
<p>A variety of sequence and associative containers are provided. Each container package defines a <i>cursor</i> type as well as a container type. A cursor is a reference to an element within a container. Many operations on cursors are common to all of the containers. A cursor referencing an element in a container is considered to be overlapping only with the element itself. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>2.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0005-1", "AI12-0196-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>The last sentence is intended to clarify that operations that just use a cursor do not interfere if the cursor objects designated different elements of the container in terms of the concurrent call rules of <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/">Annex A</a>. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>2.b/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0196-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>A cursor is not considered to overlap with other elements of the associated container, thus parallel operations involving a set of cursors each operating on mutually exclusive sets of elements from the same container are expected to work. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>2.c/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0416-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>We use the term &ldquo;container&rdquo; alone when it is clear from context what kind of entity (package, type, or object) that we are talking about. Otherwise, we use &ldquo;container package&rdquo;, &ldquo;container type&rdquo;, or &ldquo;container object&rdquo;. Note that "container type" is defined in <a href="/docs/arm/AA-4/AA-4.3#Subclause_4.3.5">4.3.5</a> for a different usage; in all of <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a> we mean &ldquo;container type&rdquo; to be one of the primary types declared in the child packages of package Containers, such as Vector, List, or Map. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>2.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0439-1"]} />
<p>Some operations of the language-defined child units of Ada.Containers have access-to-subprogram parameters. To ensure such operations are well-defined, they guard against certain actions by the designated subprogram. An action on a container that can add or remove an element is considered to <i>tamper with cursors</i>, and these are prohibited during all such operations. An action on a container that can replace an element with one of a different size is considered to <i>tamper with elements</i>, and these are prohibited during certain of such operations. The details of the specific actions that are considered to tamper with cursors or elements are defined for each child unit of Ada.Containers.<br /></p>

<MarginText>2.2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1"]} />
<p>Several of the language-defined child units of Ada.Containers include a nested package named Stable, which provides a view of a container that prohibits any operations that would tamper with elements. By using a Stable view for manipulating a container, the number of tampering checks performed while performing the operations can be reduced. The details of the Stable subpackage are defined separately for each child unit of Ada.Containers that includes such a nested package.<br /></p>

<MarginText>3/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Within this clause we provide <i>O</i>(X). Presuming f is some function of a length parameter N and t(N) is the time the operation takes (on average or worst case, as specified) for the length N, a complexity of <i>O</i>(f(N)) means that there exists a finite A such that for any N, t(N)/f(N) {"<"} A. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>3.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>Of course, an implementation can do better than a specified <i>O</i>(f(N)): for example, <i>O</i>(1) meets the requirements for <i>O</i>(log N).<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>3.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
This concept seems to have as many names as there are authors. We used &ldquo;Landau symbol&rdquo; because that's what our reference does. But we'd also seen this referred as big-O notation (sometimes written as <i>big-oh</i>), and as Bachmann notation. Whatever the name, it always has the above definition. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>4/2</MarginText>
<p>If the advice suggests that the complexity should be less than <i>O</i>(f(N)), then for any arbitrarily small positive real D, there should exist a positive integer M such that for all N {">"} M, t(N)/f(N) {"<"} D.<br /></p>

<MarginText>5/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0044-1", "AI12-0416-1"]} />
<p>When a formal function is used to provide an ordering for a container, it is generally required to define a strict weak ordering. A function "{"<"}" defines a <i>strict weak ordering</i> if it is irreflexive, asymmetric, transitive, and in addition, if <i>x</i> {"<"} <i>y</i> for any values <i>x</i> and <i>y</i>, then for all other values <i>z</i>, (<i>x</i> {"<"} <i>z</i>) or (<i>z</i> {"<"} <i>y</i>). Elements are in a <i>smallest first</i> order using such an operator if, for every element <i>y</i> with a predecessor <i>x</i> in the order, (<i>y</i> {"<"} <i>x</i>) is false.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.a.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0416-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>Given a "{"<"}" operator that provides a strict weak ordering, knowing that (<i>y</i> {"<"} <i>x</i>) is false is enough to know that (<i>x</i> {"<"}= <i>y</i>) is true. For a strict weak ordering, (<i>x</i> = <i>y</i>) when both (<i>x</i> {"<"} <i>y</i>) and (<i>y</i> {"<"} <i>x</i>) are false. Therefore, it is not necessary to use the "=" operator or test (<i>x</i> {"<"} <i>y</i>). We only need to discuss adjacent elements since a strict weak ordering is transitive. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Language Design Principles

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.a/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0299-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
This subclause provides a number of useful containers for Ada. Only the most useful containers are provided. Ones that are relatively easy to code, redundant, or rarely used are omitted from this set, even if they are generally included in containers libraries.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The containers packages are modeled on the Standard Template Library (STL), an algorithms and data structure library popularized by Alexander Stepanov, and included in the C++ standard library. The structure and terminology differ from the STL where that better maps to common Ada usage. For instance, what the STL calls &ldquo;iterators&rdquo; are called &ldquo;cursors&rdquo; here.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.c/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The following major nonlimited containers are provided:<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.d/2</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>(Expandable) Vectors of any nonlimited type;<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.e/2</MarginText>
<li>Doubly-linked Lists of any nonlimited type;<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.f/2</MarginText>
<li>Hashed Maps keyed by any nonlimited hashable type, and containing any nonlimited type;<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.g/2</MarginText>
<li>Ordered Maps keyed by any nonlimited ordered type, and containing any nonlimited type;<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.h/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0136-1"]} />
<li>Hashed Sets of any nonlimited hashable type;<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.i/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0136-1"]} />
<li>Ordered Sets of any nonlimited ordered type;<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.i.1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0136-1"]} />
<li>Multiway Trees of any nonlimited type;<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.i.2/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0069-1"]} />
<li>Holders of any (indefinite) nonlimited type;<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.i.3/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<li>Synchronized queues of any definite nonlimited type; and<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.i.4/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<li>Priority queues of any definite nonlimited type. <br /></li>
</ul>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.j/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Separate versions for definite and indefinite element types are provided, as those for definite types can be implemented more efficiently. Similarly, a separate bounded version is provided in order to give more predictable memory usage.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.k/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Each container includes a cursor, which is a reference to an element within a container. Cursors generally remain valid as long as the container exists and the element referenced is not deleted. Many operations on cursors are common to all of the containers. This makes it possible to write generic algorithms that work on any kind of container.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.l/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The containers packages are structured so that additional packages can be added in the future. Indeed, we hope that these packages provide the basis for a more extensive secondary standard for containers.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.m/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
If containers with similar functionality (but different performance characteristics) are provided (by the implementation or by a secondary standard), we suggest that a prefix be used to identify the class of the functionality: "Ada.Containers.Bounded{"_"}Sets" (for a set with a maximum number of elements); "Ada.Containers.Protected{"_"}Maps" (for a map which can be accessed by multiple tasks at one time); "Ada.Containers.Persistent{"_"}Vectors" (for a persistent vector which continues to exist between executions of a program) and so on.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.n/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Note that the language already includes several requirements that are important to the use of containers. These include:<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.o/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0196-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>Library packages must allow concurrent calls &ndash; multiple tasks can use the packages as long as they operate on separate containers. Thus, it is only necessary for a user to protect a container if a single container needs to be used by multiple tasks and concurrent calls to operations of the container have overlapping parameters.<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.p/2</MarginText>
<li>Language-defined types must stream "properly". That means that the stream attributes can be used to implement persistence of containers when necessary, and containers can be passed between partitions of a program.<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.q/2</MarginText>
<li>Equality of language-defined types must compose &ldquo;properly&rdquo;. This means that the version of "=" directly used by users is the same one that will be used in generics and in predefined equality operators of types with components of the containers and/or cursors. This prevents the abstraction from breaking unexpectedly.<br /></li>
<MarginText>5.q.1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0048-1"]} />
<li>Redispatching is not allowed (unless it is required). That means that overriding a container operation will not change the behavior of any other predefined container operation. This provides a stable base for extensions. <br /></li>
</ul>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.r/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0258-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
If a container's element type is controlled, the point at which the element is finalized will depend on the implementation of the container. For certain kinds of containers, we require finalization behavior based on the canonical implementation of the container (see the Implementation Requirements below). For the "normal" containers, we do not specify precisely where this will happen (it will happen no later than the finalization of the container, of course) in order to give implementations flexibility to cache, block, split , or reusethe nodes of the container.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.s/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0258-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<i>This paragraph was deleted.</i><br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.t/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The use of controlled types also brings up the possibility of failure of finalization (and thus deallocation) of an element. This is a &ldquo;serious bug&rdquo;, as AI95-179 puts it, so we don't try to specify what happens in that case. The implementation should propagate the exception. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.u/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>It is expected that exceptions propagated from these operations do not damage containers. That is, if Storage{"_"}Error is propagated because of an allocation failure, or Constraint{"_"}Error is propagated by the assignment of elements, the container can continue to be used without further exceptions. The intent is that it should be possible to recover from errors without losing data. We don't try to state this formally in most cases, because it is hard to define precisely what is and is not allowed behavior. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.v/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0005-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>When this clause says that the behavior of something is unspecified, we really mean that any result of executing Ada code short of erroneous execution is allowed. We do not mean that memory not belonging to the parameters of the operation can be trashed. When we mean to allow erroneous behavior, we specifically say that execution is erroneous. All this means that, if the containers are written in Ada, checks should not be suppressed or removed assuming some behavior of other code, and that the implementation should take care to avoid creating internal dangling accesses by assuming behavior from generic formals that can't be guaranteed. We don't try to say this normatively because it would be fairly complex, and implementers are unlikely to increase their support costs by fielding implementations that are unstable if given buggy hash functions, et al. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>6/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0035-1", "AI12-0449-1"]} />
<p>Certain subprograms declared within instances of some of the generic packages presented in this clause are said to <i>perform indefinite insertion</i>. These subprograms are those corresponding (in the sense of the copying described in <a href="/docs/arm/AA-12/AA-12.3">12.3</a>) to subprograms that have formal parameters of a generic formal indefinite type and that are identified as performing indefinite insertion in the subclause defining the generic package.<br /></p>

<MarginText>7/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0035-1", "AI12-0449-1"]} />
<p>If a subprogram performs indefinite insertion, then certain run-time checks are performed as part of a call to the subprogram; if any of these checks fail, then the resulting exception is propagated to the caller and the container is not modified by the call. These checks are performed for each parameter corresponding (in the sense of the copying described in <a href="/docs/arm/AA-12/AA-12.3">12.3</a>) to a parameter in the corresponding generic whose type is a generic formal indefinite type. The checks performed for a given parameter are those checks explicitly specified in <a href="/docs/arm/AA-4/AA-4.8">4.8</a> that would be performed as part of the evaluation of an initialized allocator whose access type is declared immediately within the instance, where:<br /></p>

<MarginText>8/4</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>the value of the <code><a href="/docs/arm/AA-4/AA-4.7#S0163">qualified_expression</a></code> is that of the parameter; and<br /></li>
<MarginText>9/4</MarginText>
<li>the designated subtype of the access type is the subtype of the parameter; and<br /></li>
<MarginText>10/4</MarginText>
<li>finalization of the collection of the access type has started if and only if the finalization of the instance has started. <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>10.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0449-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>The phrase "explicitly specified" means those checks for which <a href="/docs/arm/AA-4/AA-4.8">4.8</a> includes the phrase "{"<"}some exception{">"} is raised if ...". It does not refer, for example, to any checks performed as part of any subtype conversion. In particular, this wording includes the checks described in <a href="/docs/arm/AA-4/AA-4.8">4.8</a> to be performed in the case of a class-wide designated type, and of a designated subtype that has access discriminant parts. These checks are needed to prevent containers from outliving their contained (Element{"_"}Type or Key{"_"}Type) values. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>10.b/4</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>These rules have a dual purpose. Mainly, we are <i>requiring</i> checks needed to prevent dangling references. As a side effect, we are also <i>allowing</i> checks needed to permit an implementation of a container generic to make use of access types in a straightforward way. As an example of the second purpose, suppose that an implementation does declare such an access type and suppose further that the finalization of the collection of the access type has started. These rules allow Program{"_"}Error to be propagated in this case (as specified in <a href="/docs/arm/AA-4/AA-4.8">4.8</a>); this is necessary to allow an all-Ada implementation of these packages. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Implementation Requirements

<MarginText>11/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0258-1"]} />
<p>For an indefinite container (one whose type is defined in an instance of a child package of Containers whose <code><a href="/docs/arm/AA-3/AA-3.1#S0022">defining_identifier</a></code> contains "Indefinite"), each element of the container shall be created when it is inserted into the container and finalized when it is deleted from the container (or when the container object is finalized if the element has not been deleted). For a bounded container (one whose type is defined in an instance of a child package of Containers whose <code><a href="/docs/arm/AA-3/AA-3.1#S0022">defining_identifier</a></code> starts with "Bounded") that is not an indefinite container, all of the elements of the capacity of the container shall be created and default initialized when the container object is created; the elements shall be finalized when the container object is finalized. [For other kinds of containers, when elements are created and finalized is unspecified.]<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>11.a/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>This allows a user to be able to reason about the behavior of elements that have controlled parts. In most cases, such elements need to be stored in an indefinite container. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>11.b/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>If the containers are implemented in Ada, this implies that elements for an indefinite container are allocated individually, and that a bounded container contains an array of elements or other data structure that is initialized for the entire capacity of the container when it is created. There is no such restriction on the implementation of the "normal" containers; these can be handled in any way convenient to the implementation &mdash; in particular, node reuse is allowed. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>12/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p>For an instance <i>I</i> of a container package with a container type, the specific type <i>T</i> of the object returned from a function that returns an object of an iterator interface, as well as the primitive operations of <i>T</i>, shall be nonblocking. The Global aspect specified for <i>T</i> and the primitive operations of <i>T</i> shall be (<b>in all</b>, <b>out synchronized</b>) or a specification that allows access to fewer global objects.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.a/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>This requires that the traversal and iteration operations of a container do not create, destroy, or assign any objects of a formal type of <i>I</i>, nor call any formal subprograms of <i>I</i>. Those objects and subprograms might be blocking (depending on the actual parameters). We put similar requirements on the individual traversal operations in the container package definitions. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.b/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>These requirements allows users to use container iterators inside of parallel constructs, regardless of the actual parameters to the instantiation. If such an iterator allowed blocking, it would be illegal inside of a parallel construct (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-9/AA-9.5">9.5</a>). If such an iterator allowed writing of unsynchronized global objects, it would be illegal when the default conflict checking policy is in effect (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-9/AA-9.10#Subclause_9.10.1">9.10.1</a>). These requirements include sequential iterators; the iterator does not need to appear in a parallel loop to trigger these requirements. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.c/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>We have to give these requirements as a text rule, as there is no place to declare suitable aspects. The specific type of a container iterator is declared by the implementation and is not part of the visible specification (iterator functions just return a value of a class-wide type). The iterator interface itself cannot impose such a requirement since it needs to be able to work with user-defined types that do need to allow blocking. We give this as a global requirement to avoid duplication. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 95

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.d/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0299-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
This subclause is new. It just provides an introduction to the following subclauses. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Wording Changes from Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.e/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0044-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<b></b> Added a definition of strict weak ordering. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.f/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0196-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<b></b> We now say that a cursor only overlaps with the element it designates, rather than with the whole container. This allows some reading operations to operate on the container in parallel without separate synchronization. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Wording Changes from Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.g/4</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0035-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<b>Corrigendum:</b> Added a definition of &ldquo;performs indefinite insertion&rdquo;. This is used in other subclauses and any resulting inconsistencies are documented there.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.h/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Moved the basic description of tampering checks here, to cut duplication in description of the individual containers. Added a description of stable views of containers.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.i/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Added a global requirement that iterators returned from containers are nonblocking if the instance is nonblocking.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.j/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0258-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<b></b> Defined when objects are created and finalized for Bounded and Indefinite containers, so that these can be used reliably with controlled element types. This is not incompatible as this behavior was previously unspecified; code depending on specific behavior was wrong.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.k/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0005-1", "AI12-0416-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Added a definition of &ldquo;smallest first&rdquo; ordering, so that the behavior of the Sort procedures when elements are equal is well-defined. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.1"></a>

## A.18.1  The Package Containers

<MarginText>1/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The package Containers is the root of the containers subsystem. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>2/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The library package Containers has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>3/5_A.18.1</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0414-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
package Ada.Containers{"\n"}   with Pure is{"\n"}
<MarginText>4/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
   type Hash{"_"}Type is mod implementation-defined;{"\n"}
<MarginText>5/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
   type Count{"_"}Type is range 0 .. implementation-defined;{"\n"}
<MarginText>5.1/3_A.18.1</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
   Capacity{"_"}Error : exception;{"\n"}
<MarginText>6/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
end Ada.Containers;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>7/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Hash{"_"}Type represents the range of the result of a hash function. Count{"_"}Type represents the (potential or actual) number of elements of a container. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>7.a/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-defined">
<b></b>The value of Containers.Hash{"_"}Type'Modulus. The value of Containers.Count{"_"}Type'Last.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>7.1/3_A.18.1</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>Capacity{"_"}Error is raised when the capacity of a container is exceeded.<br /></p>


#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>8/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Hash{"_"}Type'Modulus should be at least 2{"*"}{"*"}32. Count{"_"}Type'Last should be at least 2{"*"}{"*"}31&ndash;1. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>8.a/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<b></b>Containers.Hash{"_"}Type'Modulus should be at least 2{"*"}{"*"}32. Containers.Count{"_"}Type'Last should be at least 2{"*"}{"*"}31&ndash;1.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>8.b/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>This is not a requirement so that these types can be declared properly on machines with native sizes that are not 32 bits. For instance, a 24-bit target could use 2{"*"}{"*"}24 for Hash{"_"}Type'Modulus. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 95

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>8.c/2_A.18.1</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The package Containers is new. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Incompatibilities With Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>8.d/3_A.18.1</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Exception Capacity{"_"}Error is added to Containers. If Containers is referenced in a <code><a href="/docs/arm/AA-8/AA-8.4#S0235">use_clause</a></code>, and an entity with the name Capacity{"_"}Error is defined in a package that is also referenced in a <code><a href="/docs/arm/AA-8/AA-8.4#S0235">use_clause</a></code>, the entity Capacity{"_"}Error may no longer be use-visible, resulting in errors. This should be rare and is easily fixed if it does occur. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.2"></a>

## A.18.2  The Generic Package Containers.Vectors

<MarginText>1/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Vectors provides private types Vector and Cursor, and a set of operations for each type. A vector container allows insertion and deletion at any position, but it is specifically optimized for insertion and deletion at the high end (the end with the higher index) of the container. A vector container also provides random access to its elements. <br /></p>

<MarginText>2/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<p>A vector container behaves conceptually as an array that expands as necessary as items are inserted. The <i>length</i> of a vector is the number of elements that the vector contains. The <i>capacity</i> of a vector is the maximum number of elements that can be inserted into the vector prior to it being automatically expanded.<br /></p>

<MarginText>3/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<p>Elements in a vector container can be referred to by an index value of a generic formal type. The first element of a vector always has its index value equal to the lower bound of the formal type.<br /></p>

<MarginText>4/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<p>A vector container may contain <i>empty elements</i>. Empty elements do not have a specified value.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>4.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>Vectors are not intended to be sparse (that is, there are elements at all defined positions). Users are expected to use other containers (like a Map) when they need sparse structures (there is a Note to this effect at the end of this subclause).<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>4.b/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The internal array is a conceptual model of a vector. There is no requirement for an implementation to be a single contiguous array. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>5/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The generic library package Containers.Vectors has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>6/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0084-1", "AI05-0212-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
with Ada.Iterator{"_"}Interfaces;{"\n"}generic{"\n"}   type Index{"_"}Type is range {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}   type Element{"_"}Type is private;{"\n"}   with function "=" (Left, Right : Element{"_"}Type){"\n"}      return Boolean is {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}package Ada.Containers.Vectors{"\n"}   with Preelaborate, Remote{"_"}Types,{"\n"}        Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in out synchronized is{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>6.a/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>For the Global aspect, any side-effects of the actual parameters of an instance are ignored. So Global ={">"} <b>in out synchronized</b> means that the only global side-effects allowed are associated with the actual generic parameters of the instance or with any synchronized state. Unsynchronized package state is not allowed for any container package, and pure packages do not allow any package state at all (they typically have Global ={">"} <b>null</b>).<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>6.b/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Similarly, when Nonblocking is set to True for a generic unit, it still includes the blocking effects of the actual parameters to the instance. Thus, the only blocking allowed is that associated with the actual generic parameters. If none of the actual paramerters allow blocking, then no operation of the generic instance may block. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>7/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   subtype Extended{"_"}Index is{"\n"}      Index{"_"}Type'Base range{"\n"}         Index{"_"}Type'First-1 ..{"\n"}         Index{"_"}Type'Min (Index{"_"}Type'Base'Last - 1, Index{"_"}Type'Last) + 1;{"\n"}   No{"_"}Index : constant Extended{"_"}Index := Extended{"_"}Index'First;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>7.a/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>The base type of a scalar type is always nonblocking and has Global ={">"} <b>null</b>. Therefore, so long as this type is used in the implementation, whether or not the actual type for Index{"_"}Type allows blocking or side-effects does not matter. Therefore, we require that operations that only operate on the container implementation be nonblocking and have Global ={">"} <b>null</b> regardless of the actual parameters. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>8/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1", "AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0112-1", "AI12-0212-1", "AI12-0339-1", "AI12-0399-1", "AI12-0400-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   type Vector is tagged private{"\n"}      with Constant{"_"}Indexing ={">"} Constant{"_"}Reference,{"\n"}           Variable{"_"}Indexing ={">"} Reference,{"\n"}           Default{"_"}Iterator  ={">"} Iterate,{"\n"}           Iterator{"_"}Element  ={">"} Element{"_"}Type,{"\n"}           Iterator{"_"}View     ={">"} Stable.Vector,{"\n"}           Aggregate         ={">"} (Empty          ={">"} Empty,{"\n"}                                 Add{"_"}Unnamed    ={">"} Append,{"\n"}                                 New{"_"}Indexed    ={">"} New{"_"}Vector,{"\n"}                                 Assign{"_"}Indexed ={">"} Replace{"_"}Element),{"\n"}           Stable{"_"}Properties ={">"} (Length, Capacity,{"\n"}                                 Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited,{"\n"}                                 Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited),{"\n"}           Default{"_"}Initial{"_"}Condition ={">"}{"\n"}              Length (Vector) = 0 and then{"\n"}              (not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Vector)) and then{"\n"}              (not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited (Vector)),{"\n"}           Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization;{"\n"}
<MarginText>9/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0399-1"]} />
   type Cursor is private{"\n"}      with Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization;{"\n"}
<MarginText>10/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
   Empty{"_"}Vector : constant Vector;{"\n"}
<MarginText>11/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
   No{"_"}Element : constant Cursor;{"\n"}
<MarginText>11.1/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
   function Has{"_"}Element (Position : Cursor) return Boolean{"\n"}      with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in all, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>11.a/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>Any operation that takes a cursor but no vector can read the vector associated with the cursor. We only know that there is some object of type Vector. Since we don't have a global specification that describes all objects of a specific type, we have to allow reading any object by specifying <b>in all</b>. For such functions, we don't allow writing any object, even those associated with generic formal parameters, thus we also specify Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} <b>null</b>. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>11.2/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   function Has{"_"}Element (Container : Vector; Position : Cursor){"\n"}      return Boolean{"\n"}      with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>11.b/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>For operations that do not depend on any of the operations of the generic formal parameters (including those of formal types), we specify that the operation has no side-effects of any kind. This requires specifying that there is no dependence on the generic formal parameters with Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} <b>null</b> in addition to no usual side-effects with <b>null</b>. We also specify Nonblocking on such operations in order that the operation never blocks even if some of the actual parameters allow blocking. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>11.3/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">

<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />

Last{"_"}Index (Container){"\n"}                      or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error,{"\n"}           Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} Element{"_"}Type;{"\n"}

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>27.a/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>Here the Nonblocking and Global contracts are saying that Element depends on the properties of the actual for Element{"_"}Type, but not on the properties of the actuals for Index{"_"}Type or "=". <MarginText>79.a/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>The Global of <b>null</b> assumes that the user of a stable object is including effects associated with the access discriminant. For operations with <b>in</b> parameters (after any overriding), the object designated by the access discriminant is assumed to be read, and for other operations (including initialization and finalization) the object designated by the access discriminant is assumed to be read and updated. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>83/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The actual function for the generic formal function "=" on Element{"_"}Type values is expected to define a reflexive and symmetric relationship and return the same result value each time it is called with a particular pair of values. If it behaves in some other manner, the functions defined to use it return an unspecified value. The exact arguments and number of calls of this generic formal function by the functions defined to use it are unspecified.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>83.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>The &ldquo;functions defined to use it&rdquo; are Find, Find{"_"}Index, Reverse{"_"}Find, Reverse{"_"}Find{"_"}Index, and "=" for Vectors. This list is a bit too long to give explicitly.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>83.b/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
If the actual function for "=" is not symmetric and consistent, the result returned by any of the functions defined to use "=" cannot be predicted. The implementation is not required to protect against "=" raising an exception, or returning random results, or any other &ldquo;bad&rdquo; behavior. And it can call "=" in whatever manner makes sense. But note that only the results of the functions defined to use "=" are unspecified; other subprograms are not allowed to break if "=" is bad. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>84/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The type Vector is used to represent vectors. The type Vector needs finalization (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-7/AA-7.6">7.6</a>).<br /></p>

<MarginText>85/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Empty{"_"}Vector represents the empty vector object. It has a length of 0. If an object of type Vector is not otherwise initialized, it is initialized to the same value as Empty{"_"}Vector.<br /></p>

<MarginText>86/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>No{"_"}Element represents a cursor that designates no element. If an object of type Cursor is not otherwise initialized, it is initialized to the same value as No{"_"}Element.<br /></p>

<MarginText>87/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI12-0434-1"]} />
<p>The primitive "=" operator for type Cursor returns True if both cursors are No{"_"}Element, or designate the same element in the same container.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>87.a/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0434-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<b>To be honest: </b>&ldquo;The primitive "=" operator&rdquo; is the one with two parameters of type Cursor which returns Boolean. We're not talking about some other (hidden) primitive function named "=". <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>88/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Execution of the default implementation of the Input, Output, Read, or Write attribute of type Cursor raises Program{"_"}Error.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>88.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>A cursor will probably be implemented in terms of one or more access values, and the effects of streaming access values is unspecified. Rather than letting the user stream junk by accident, we mandate that streaming of cursors raise Program{"_"}Error by default. The attributes can always be specified if there is a need to support streaming. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>88.1/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0262-1", "AI12-0437-1"]} />
<p>Vector'Write for a Vector object <i>V</i> writes Length(<i>V</i>) elements of the vector to the stream. It may also write additional information about the vector.<br /></p>

<MarginText>88.2/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>Vector'Read reads the representation of a vector from the stream, and assigns to <i>Item</i> a vector with the same length and elements as was written by Vector'Write.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>88.b/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>The Reference Manual requires streaming of all language-defined nonlimited types (including containers) to "work" (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-13/AA-13.13#Subclause_13.13.2">13.13.2</a>). In addition, we do not want all of the elements that make up the capacity of the vector streamed, as those beyond the length of the container have undefined contents (and might cause bad things when read back in). This will require a custom stream attribute implementation; the language-defined default implementation will not work (even for a bounded form, as that would most likely stream the entire capacity of the vector). There is a separate requirement that the unbounded and Bounded form use the same streaming representation for the same element type, see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.19">A.18.19</a>. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>89/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>No{"_"}Index represents a position that does not correspond to any element. The subtype Extended{"_"}Index includes the indices covered by Index{"_"}Type plus the value No{"_"}Index and, if it exists, the successor to the Index{"_"}Type'Last.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>89.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>We require the existence of Index{"_"}Type'First &ndash; 1, so that No{"_"}Index and Last{"_"}Index of an empty vector is well-defined. We don't require the existence of Index{"_"}Type'Last + 1, as it is only used as the position of insertions (and needs to be allowed only when inserting an empty vector). <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>90/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p>[Some operations check for &ldquo;tampering with cursors&rdquo; of a container because they depend on the set of elements of the container remaining constant, and others check for &ldquo;tampering with elements&rdquo; of a container because they depend on elements of the container not being replaced.] When tampering with cursors is <i>prohibited</i> for a particular vector object <i>V</i>, Program{"_"}Error is propagated by the finalization of <i>V</i>[, as well as by a call that passes <i>V</i> to certain of the operations of this package, as indicated by the precondition of such an operation]. Similarly, when tampering with elements is <i>prohibited</i> for <i>V</i>, Program{"_"}Error is propagated by a call that passes <i>V</i> to certain of the other operations of this package, as indicated by the precondition of such an operation.<br /></p>

<p><i>Paragraphs 91 through 97 are removed as preconditions now describe these rules.</i> <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>93.a.1/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>We don't need to explicitly mention <code><a href="/docs/arm/AA-5/AA-5.2#S0173">assignment_statement</a></code>, because that finalizes the target object as part of the operation, and finalization of an object is already defined as tampering with cursors. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>97.2/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Has{"_"}Element (Position : Cursor) return Boolean{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in all, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>97.3/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns True if Position designates an element, and returns False otherwise.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>97.c/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0005-1", "AI05-0212-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<b>To be honest: </b>This function might not detect cursors that designate deleted elements; such cursors are invalid (see below) and the result of calling Has{"_"}Element with an invalid cursor is unspecified (but not erroneous). <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>97.4/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Has{"_"}Element (Container : Vector; Position : Cursor){"\n"}   return Boolean{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>97.5/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns True if Position designates an element in Container, and returns False otherwise.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>97.d/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>If Position is No{"_"}Element, Has{"_"}Element returns False. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>98/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function "=" (Left, Right : Vector) return Boolean;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>99/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If Left and Right denote the same vector object, then the function returns True. If Left and Right have different lengths, then the function returns False. Otherwise, it compares each element in Left to the corresponding element in Right using the generic formal equality operator. If any such comparison returns False, the function returns False; otherwise, it returns True. Any exception raised during evaluation of element equality is propagated.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>99.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>This wording describes the canonical semantics. However, the order and number of calls on the formal equality function is unspecified for all of the operations that use it in this package, so an implementation can call it as many or as few times as it needs to get the correct answer. Specifically, there is no requirement to call the formal equality additional times once the answer has been determined. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>99.1/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited{"\n"}   (Container : Vector) return Boolean{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>99.2/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns True if tampering with cursors or tampering with elements is currently prohibited for Container, and returns False otherwise.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>99.b/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>Prohibiting tampering with elements also needs to prohibit tampering with cursors, as deleting an element is similar to replacing it. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>99.c/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>Various contracts elsewhere in this specification require that this function be implemented with synchronized data. Moreover, it is possible for tampering to be prohibited by multiple operations (sequentially or in parallel). Therefore, tampering needs to be implemented with an atomic or protected counter. The counter is initialized to zero, and is incremented when tampering is prohibited, and decremented when leaving an area that prohibited tampering. Function Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited returns True if the counter is nonzero. (Note that any case where the result is not well-defined for one task is incorrect use of shared variables and would be erroneous by the rules of <a href="/docs/arm/AA-9/AA-9.10">9.10</a>, so no special protection is needed to read the counter.) <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>99.3/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited{"\n"}   (Container : Vector) return Boolean{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>99.4/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Always returns False[, regardless of whether tampering with elements is prohibited].<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>99.d/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>A definite element cannot change size, so we allow operations that tamper with elements even when tampering with elements is prohibited. That's not true for the indefinite containers, which is why this kind of tampering exists. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>99.5/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Maximum{"_"}Length return Count{"_"}Type{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>99.6/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns the maximum Length of a Vector, based on the index type.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>99.e/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>This is just:<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>99.f_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  {"\n"}  Count{"_"}Type (Index{"_"}Type'Last - Index{"_"}Type'First + 1){"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>99.g/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
but since the inner calculation can overflow or the type conversion can fail, this can't be evaluated in general with an expression function. Note that if this expression raises Constraint{"_"}Error, then the result is Count{"_"}Type'Last, since the Capacity of a Vector cannot exceed Count{"_"}Type'Last. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>99.7/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Empty (Capacity : Count{"_"}Type := implementation-defined){"\n"}   return Vector{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Capacity {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length{"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} {"\n"}           Capacity (Empty'Result) {">"}= Capacity and then{"\n"}           not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited (Empty'Result) and then{"\n"}           not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Empty'Result) and then{"\n"}           Length (Empty'Result) = 0;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>99.8/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0339-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns an empty vector.<br /></p>

<MarginText>100/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function To{"_"}Vector (Length : Count{"_"}Type) return Vector{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Length {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"}{"\n"}           To{"_"}Vector'Result.Length = Length and then{"\n"}           not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited (To{"_"}Vector'Result){"\n"}             and then{"\n"}           not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (To{"_"}Vector'Result){"\n"}             and then{"\n"}           To{"_"}Vector'Result.Capacity {">"}= Length;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>101/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns a vector with a length of Length, filled with empty elements.<br /></p>

<MarginText>102/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function To{"_"}Vector{"\n"}  (New{"_"}Item : Element{"_"}Type;{"\n"}   Length   : Count{"_"}Type) return Vector{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Length {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"}{"\n"}           To{"_"}Vector'Result.Length = Length and then{"\n"}           not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited (To{"_"}Vector'Result){"\n"}             and then{"\n"}           not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (To{"_"}Vector'Result){"\n"}             and then{"\n"}        To{"_"}Vector'Result.Capacity {">"}= Length;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>103/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns a vector with a length of Length, filled with elements initialized to the value New{"_"}Item.<br /></p>

<MarginText>104/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function "&" (Left, Right : Vector) return Vector{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Length (Left) {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length - Length (Right){"\n"}                 or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Length (Vectors."&"'Result) ={"\n"}                   Length (Left) + Length (Right) and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited (Vectors."&"'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Vectors."&"'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                Vectors."&"'Result.Capacity {">"}={"\n"}                   Length (Left) + Length (Right);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>105/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns a vector comprising the elements of Left followed by the elements of Right.<br /></p>

<MarginText>106/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function "&" (Left  : Vector;{"\n"}              Right : Element{"_"}Type) return Vector{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Length (Left) {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length - 1{"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Vectors."&"'Result.Length = Length (Left) + 1 and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited (Vectors."&"'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Vectors."&"'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                Vectors."&"'Result.Capacity {">"}= Length (Left) + 1;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>107/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns a vector comprising the elements of Left followed by the element Right.<br /></p>

<MarginText>108/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function "&" (Left  : Element{"_"}Type;{"\n"}              Right : Vector) return Vector{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Length (Right) {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length - 1{"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Length (Vectors."&"'Result) = Length (Right) + 1 and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited (Vectors."&"'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Vectors."&"'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                Vectors."&"'Result.Capacity {">"}= Length (Right) + 1;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>109/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns a vector comprising the element Left followed by the elements of Right.<br /></p>

<MarginText>110/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function "&" (Left, Right  : Element{"_"}Type) return Vector{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Maximum{"_"}Length {">"}= 2 or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Length ("&"'Result) = 2 and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited (Vectors."&"'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Vectors."&"'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                Vectors."&"'Result.Capacity {">"}= 2;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>111/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns a vector comprising the element Left followed by the element Right.<br /></p>

<MarginText>112/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Capacity (Container : Vector) return Count{"_"}Type{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>113/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns the capacity of Container.<br /></p>

<MarginText>114/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Reserve{"_"}Capacity (Container : in out Vector;{"\n"}                            Capacity  : in     Count{"_"}Type){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                 or else raise Program{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Container.Capacity {">"}= Capacity;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>115/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If the capacity of Container is already greater than or equal to Capacity, then Reserve{"_"}Capacity has no effect. Otherwise, Reserve{"_"}Capacity allocates additional storage as necessary to ensure that the length of the resulting vector can become at least the value Capacity without requiring an additional call to Reserve{"_"}Capacity, and is large enough to hold the current length of Container. Reserve{"_"}Capacity then, as necessary, moves elements into the new storage and deallocates any storage no longer needed. Any exception raised during allocation is propagated and Container is not modified.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>115.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>Expanding the internal array can be done by allocating a new, longer array, copying the elements, and deallocating the original array. This may raise Storage{"_"}Error, or cause an exception from a controlled subprogram. We require that a failed Reserve{"_"}Capacity does not lose any elements if an exception occurs, but we do not require a specific order of evaluations or copying.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>115.b/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
This routine is used to preallocate the internal array to the specified capacity such that future Inserts do not require memory allocation overhead. Therefore, the implementation should allocate the needed memory to make that true at this point, even though the visible semantics could be preserved by waiting until the memory is needed. This doesn't apply to the indefinite element container, because elements will have to be allocated individually.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>115.c/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The implementation does not have to contract the internal array if the capacity is reduced, as any capacity greater than or equal to the specified capacity is allowed.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>116/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Length (Container : Vector) return Count{"_"}Type{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>117/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns the number of elements in Container.<br /></p>

<MarginText>118/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Set{"_"}Length (Container : in out Vector;{"\n"}                      Length    : in     Count{"_"}Type){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} (not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                   or else raise Program{"_"}Error) and then{"\n"}                (Length {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error),{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Container.Length = Length and then{"\n"}                Capacity (Container) {">"}= Length;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>119/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If Length is larger than the capacity of Container, Set{"_"}Length calls Reserve{"_"}Capacity (Container, Length), then sets the length of the Container to Length. If Length is greater than the original length of Container, empty elements are added to Container; otherwise, elements are removed from Container.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>119.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>No elements are moved by this operation; any new empty elements are added at the end. This follows from the rules that a cursor continues to designate the same element unless the routine is defined to make the cursor ambiguous or invalid; this operation does not do that. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>120/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Is{"_"}Empty (Container : Vector) return Boolean{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Is{"_"}Empty'Result = (Length (Container) = 0);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>121/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns True if Container is empty.<br /></p>

<MarginText>122/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Clear (Container : in out Vector){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                    or else raise Program{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Length (Container) = 0;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>123/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Removes all the elements from Container. The capacity of Container does not change.<br /></p>

<MarginText>124/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function To{"_"}Cursor (Container : Vector;{"\n"}                    Index     : Extended{"_"}Index) return Cursor{"\n"}   with Post ={">"} (if Index in{"\n"}                    First{"_"}Index (Container) .. Last{"_"}Index (Container){"\n"}                 then Has{"_"}Element (Container, To{"_"}Cursor'Result){"\n"}                 else To{"_"}Cursor'Result = No{"_"}Element),{"\n"}        Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>125/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI12-0112-1", "AI12-0196-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns a cursor designating the element at position Index in Container; returns No{"_"}Element if Index does not designate an element. For the purposes of determining whether the parameters overlap in a call to To{"_"}Cursor, the Container parameter is not considered to overlap with any object [(including itself)].<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>125.a/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0196-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>Without the preceding rule, concurrent calls to To{"_"}Cursor on the same container would interfere by the concurrent call rules in <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/">Annex A</a>, since the container object of the concurrent calls would overlap with itself. We want these to not interfere, for example to allow the Vector elements to be split into separate &ldquo;chunks&rdquo; for parallel processing. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>126/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function To{"_"}Index (Position  : Cursor) return Extended{"_"}Index{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in all, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>127/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If Position is No{"_"}Element, No{"_"}Index is returned. Otherwise, the index (within its containing vector) of the element designated by Position is returned.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>127.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>This implies that the index is determinable from a bare cursor alone. The basic model is that a vector cursor is implemented as a record containing an access to the vector container and an index value. This does constrain implementations, but it also allows all of the cursor operations to be defined in terms of the corresponding index operation (which should be primary for a vector). <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>127.1/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function To{"_"}Index (Container : Vector;{"\n"}                   Position  : Cursor) return Extended{"_"}Index{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Position = No{"_"}Element or else{"\n"}                Has{"_"}Element (Container, Position)  or else{"\n"}                   raise Program{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} (if Position = No{"_"}Element then To{"_"}Index'Result = No{"_"}Index{"\n"}                 else To{"_"}Index'Result in First{"_"}Index (Container) ..{"\n"}                        Last{"_"}Index (Container)),{"\n"}        Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>127.2/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns the index (within Container) of the element designated by Position; returns No{"_"}Index if Position does not designate an element. For the purposes of determining whether the parameters overlap in a call to To{"_"}Index, the Container parameter is not considered to overlap with any object [(including itself)].<br /></p>

<MarginText>128/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Element (Container : Vector;{"\n"}                  Index     : Index{"_"}Type){"\n"}   return Element{"_"}Type{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Index in First{"_"}Index (Container) .. Last{"_"}Index (Container){"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} Element{"_"}Type;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>129/5_A.18.2</MarginText>

<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>The &ldquo;tamper with the elements&rdquo; check is intended to prevent the Element parameter of Process from being replaced or deleted outside of Process. The check prevents data loss (if Element{"_"}Type is passed by copy) or erroneous execution (if Element{"_"}Type is an unconstrained type in an indefinite container). <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<p class="Indented4">If Element{"_"}Type is unconstrained and definite, then the actual Element parameter of Process.<b>all</b> shall be unconstrained.<br /></p>

<MarginText>147.19/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Assign (Target : in out Vector; Source : in Vector){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Target){"\n"}                   or else raise Program{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Length (Source) = Length (Target) and then{"\n"}                Capacity (Target) {">"}= Length (Target);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>147.20/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0248-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If Target denotes the same object as Source, the operation has no effect. If the length of Source is greater than the capacity of Target, Reserve{"_"}Capacity (Target, Length (Source)) is called. The elements of Source are then copied to Target as for an <code><a href="/docs/arm/AA-5/AA-5.2#S0173">assignment_statement</a></code> assigning Source to Target (this includes setting the length of Target to be that of Source). <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>147.b/3_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0005-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>This routine exists for compatibility with the bounded vector container. For an unbounded vector, Assign(A, B) and A := B behave identically. For a bounded vector, := will raise an exception if the container capacities are different, while Assign will not raise an exception if there is enough room in the target. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>147.21/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Copy (Source : Vector; Capacity : Count{"_"}Type := 0){"\n"}   return Vector{"\n"}   with Pre ={">"} Capacity = 0 or else Capacity {">"}= Length (Source){"\n"}                   or else raise Capacity{"_"}Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Length (Copy'Result) = Length (Source) and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Elements{"_"}Prohibited (Copy'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Copy'Result){"\n"}                   and then{"\n"}                Copy'Result.Capacity {">"}= (if Capacity = 0 then{"\n"}                   Length (Source) else Capacity);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>147.22/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns a vector whose elements are initialized from the corresponding elements of Source.<br /></p>

<MarginText>148/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Move (Target : in out Vector;{"\n"}                Source : in out Vector){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} (not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Target){"\n"}                   or else raise Program{"_"}Error) and then{"\n"}                (not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Source){"\n"}                   or else raise Program{"_"}Error),{"\n"}        Post ={">"} (if not Target'Has{"_"}Same{"_"}Storage (Source) then{"\n"}                    Length (Target) = Length (Source)'Old and then{"\n"}                    Length (Source) = 0 and then{"\n"}                    Capacity (Target) {">"}= Length (Source)'Old);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>149/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0248-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If Target denotes the same object as Source, then the operation has no effect. Otherwise, Move first calls Reserve{"_"}Capacity (Target, Length (Source)) and then Clear (Target); then, each element from Source is removed from Source and inserted into Target in the original order.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>149.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<b></b>The idea is that the internal array is removed from Source and moved to Target. (See the  for Move). If Capacity (Target) /= 0, the previous internal array may need to be deallocated. We don't mention this explicitly, because it is covered by the "no memory loss" Implementation Requirement. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>150/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Insert{"_"}Vector (Container : in out Vector;{"\n"}                         Before    : in     Extended{"_"}Index;{"\n"}                         New{"_"}Item  : in     Vector){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} (not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                   or else raise Program{"_"}Error) and then{"\n"}                (Before in{"\n"}                   First{"_"}Index (Container) .. Last{"_"}Index (Container) + 1{"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error) and then{"\n"}                (Length (Container) {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length - Length (New{"_"}Item){"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error),{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Length (Container)'Old + Length (New{"_"}Item) ={"\n"}                   Length (Container) and then{"\n"}                Capacity (Container) {">"}= Length (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>151/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0264-1", "AI12-0112-1", "AI12-0400-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If Length(New{"_"}Item) is 0, then Insert{"_"}Vector does nothing. Otherwise, it computes the new length <i>NL</i> as the sum of the current length and Length (New{"_"}Item); if the value of Last appropriate for length <i>NL</i> would be greater than Index{"_"}Type'Last, then Constraint{"_"}Error is propagated.<br /></p>

<MarginText>152/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0400-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If the current vector capacity is less than <i>NL</i>, Reserve{"_"}Capacity (Container, <i>NL</i>) is called to increase the vector capacity. Then Insert{"_"}Vector slides the elements in the range Before .. Last{"_"}Index (Container) up by Length(New{"_"}Item) positions, and then copies the elements of New{"_"}Item to the positions starting at Before. Any exception raised during the copying is propagated.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>152.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>Moving the elements does not necessarily involve copying. Similarly, since Reserve{"_"}Capacity does not require the copying of elements, it does not need to be explicitly called (the implementation can combine the operations if it wishes to). <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>153/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Insert{"_"}Vector (Container : in out Vector;{"\n"}                         Before    : in     Cursor;{"\n"}                         New{"_"}Item  : in     Vector){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} (not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                   or else raise Program{"_"}Error) and then{"\n"}                (Before = No{"_"}Element or else{"\n"}                 Has{"_"}Element (Container, Before){"\n"}                   or else raise Program{"_"}Error) and then{"\n"}                (Length (Container) {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length - Length (New{"_"}Item){"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error),{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Length (Container)'Old + Length (New{"_"}Item) ={"\n"}                   Length (Container) and then{"\n"}                Capacity (Container) {">"}= Length (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>154/5_A.18.2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0264-1", "AI12-0112-1", "AI12-0400-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If Length(New{"_"}Item) is 0, then Insert{"_"}Vector does nothing. If Before is No{"_"}Element, then the call is equivalent to Insert{"_"}Vector (Container, Last{"_"}Index (Container) + 1, New{"_"}Item); otherwise, the call is equivalent to Insert{"_"}Vector (Container, To{"_"}Index (Before), New{"_"}Item);<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>154.a/2_A.18.2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>The check on Before checks that the cursor does not belong to some other Container. This check implies that a reference to the container is included in the cursor value. This wording is not meant to require detection of dangling cursors; such cursors are defined to be invalid, which means that execution is erroneous, and any result is allowed (including not raising an exception). <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0257-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>If Count equals 0, Position will designate the element designated by Before, rather than a newly inserted element. Otherwise, Position will designate the first newly inserted element. <br />

Last{"_"}Index (Container) + 1{"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error) and then{"\n"}                (Length (Container) {"<"}= Maximum{"_"}Length - Count{"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error),{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Length (Container)'Old + Count = Length (Container) and then{"\n"}                Capacity (Container) {">"}= Length (Container);{"\n"}
