#### Incompatibilities With Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>21.b/5_A.18.23</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0409-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<b></b>A bounded set now only has Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization (abbreviated PI in this note) when the actual for the Element{"_"}Type has PI. If an program used a set whose actual Element{"_"}Type does not have PI in a context when PI is required (such as a library-level object in a preelaborated unit or as a component of a type with PI), the program would be illegal in Ada 2022 but legal in original Ada 2012. This situation is unlikely, especially as some existing Ada 2012 implementations reject the instance in this case. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.24"></a>

## A.18.24  The Generic Package Containers.Bounded_Ordered_Sets

<MarginText>1/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Bounded{"_"}Ordered{"_"}Sets provides a private type Set and a set of operations. It provides the same operations as the package Containers.Ordered{"_"}Sets (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.9">A.18.9</a>), with the difference that the maximum storage is bounded. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>2/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<p>The declaration of the generic library package Containers.Bounded{"_"}Ordered{"_"}Sets has the same contents and semantics as Containers.Ordered{"_"}Sets except:<br /></p>

<MarginText>3/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>The aspect Preelaborate is replaced with aspect Pure. Aspect Global is deleted.<br /></li>
<MarginText>4/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<li>The type Set is declared with a discriminant that specifies the capacity (maximum number of elements) as follows: <br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>5/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  type Set (Capacity : Count{"_"}Type) is tagged private...{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>5.1/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0409-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>The <code><a href="/docs/arm/AA-13/AA-13.1#S0348">aspect_definition</a></code> for Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization for type Set is changed to: <br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>5.2/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization ={">"}{"\n"}     Element{"_"}Type'Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>6/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>The type Set needs finalization if and only if type Element{"_"}Type needs finalization.<br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>6.a/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>The type Set cannot depend on package Ada.Finalization unless the element type depends on that package. The objects returned from the Iterator and Reference functions probably do depend on package Ada.Finalization. Restricted environments may need to avoid use of those functions and their associated types. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>6.1/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0339-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>The function Empty is replaced by:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>6.2/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   function Empty (Capacity : Count{"_"}Type := implementation-defined){"\n"}      return Set{"\n"}      with Post ={">"}{"\n"}            Empty'Result.Capacity = Capacity and then{"\n"}            not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Empty'Result) and then{"\n"}            Length (Empty'Result) = 0;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>7/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>For procedures Insert and Include, the part of the precondition reading:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>7.1/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
     ({"<"}some length{">"} {"<"}= Count{"_"}Type'Last - {"<"}some other length{">"}{"\n"}        or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error){"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>7.2/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>is replaced by:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>7.3/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
     ({"<"}some length{">"} {"<"}= Count{"_"}Type'Last - {"<"}some other length{">"}{"\n"}        or else raise Constraint{"_"}Error) and then{"\n"}     ({"<"}some length{">"} {"<"}= Container.Capacity - {"<"}some other length{">"}{"\n"}        or else raise Capacity{"_"}Error){"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>8/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>In procedure Assign, the precondition is altered to:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>8.1/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   Pre ={">"} (not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Target){"\n"}             or else raise Program{"_"}Error) and then{"\n"}          (Length (Source) {"<"}= Target.Capacity{"\n"}             or else raise Capacity{"_"}Error),{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>9/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>The function Copy is replaced with: <br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>10/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  function Copy (Source   : Set;{"\n"}                 Capacity : Count{"_"}Type := 0) return Map{"\n"}     with Pre  ={">"} Capacity = 0 or else Capacity {">"}= Length (Source){"\n"}                     or else raise Capacity{"_"}Error,{"\n"}          Post ={">"} {"\n"}             Length (Copy'Result) = Length (Source) and then{"\n"}             not Tampering{"_"}With{"_"}Cursors{"_"}Prohibited (Copy'Result) and then{"\n"}             Copy'Result.Capacity = (if Capacity = 0 then{"\n"}                Length (Source) else Capacity);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>11/5_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns a set with key/element pairs initialized from the values in Source. <br /></p>


#### Bounded (Run-Time) Errors

<MarginText>12/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0160-1", "AI05-0265-1"]} />
<p>It is a bounded error to assign from a bounded set object while tampering with elements [or cursors] of that object is prohibited. Either Program{"_"}Error is raised by the assignment, execution proceeds with the target object prohibiting tampering with elements [or cursors], or execution proceeds normally. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.a/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="proof">
<b></b>Tampering with elements includes tampering with cursors, so we only really need to talk about tampering with elements here; we mention cursors for clarity. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Erroneous Execution

<MarginText>13/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0265-1"]} />
<p>When a bounded set object <i>S</i> is finalized, if tampering with cursors is prohibited for <i>S</i> other than due to an assignment from another set, then execution is erroneous. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>13.a/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>This is a tampering event, but since the implementation is not allowed to use Ada.Finalization, it is not possible in a pure Ada implementation to detect this error. (There is no Finalize routine that will be called that could make the check.) Since the check probably cannot be made, the bad effects that could occur (such as an iterator going into an infinite loop or accessing a nonexistent element) cannot be prevented and we have to allow anything. We do allow re-assigning an object that only prohibits tampering because it was copied from another object as that cannot cause any negative effects. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Implementation Requirements

<MarginText>14/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0184-1", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p>For each instance of Containers.Ordered{"_"}Sets and each instance of Containers.Bounded{"_"}Ordered{"_"}Sets, if the two instances meet the following conditions, then the output generated by the Set'Output or Set'Write subprograms of either instance shall be readable by the Set'Input or Set'Read of the other instance, respectively:<br /></p>

<MarginText>15/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0184-1", "AI05-0248-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>the Element{"_"}Type parameters of the two instances are statically matching subtypes of the same type; and<br /></li>
<MarginText>16/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0184-1"]} />
<li>the output generated by Element{"_"}Type'Output or Element{"_"}Type'Write is readable by Element{"_"}Type'Input or Element{"_"}Type'Read, respectively (where Element{"_"}Type denotes the type of the two actual Element{"_"}Type parameters). <br /></li>
</ul>

#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>17/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0269-1"]} />
<p>Bounded ordered set objects should be implemented without implicit pointers or dynamic allocation. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.a.1/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<b></b>Bounded ordered set objects should be implemented without implicit pointers or dynamic allocation.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>18/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<p>The implementation advice for procedure Move to minimize copying does not apply. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>18.a.1/3_A.18.24</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<b></b>The implementation advice for procedure Move to minimize copying does not apply to bounded ordered sets.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>

<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
 The generic package Containers.Bounded{"_"}Ordered{"_"}Sets is new. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

If an program used a set whose actual Element{"_"}Type does not have PI in a context when PI is required (such as a library-level object in a preelaborated unit or as a component of a type with PI), the program would be illegal in Ada 2022 but legal in original Ada 2012. This situation is unlikely, especially as some existing Ada 2012 implementations reject the instance in this case. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

#### Bounded (Run-Time) Errors

<MarginText>14/3_A.18.25</MarginText>

<MarginText>15/3_A.18.25</MarginText>

<p>When a bounded tree object <i>T</i> is finalized, if tampering with cursors is prohibited for <i>T</i> other than due to an assignment from another tree, then execution is erroneous. <br /></p>

<MarginText>17/3_A.18.25</MarginText>

</ul>

<MarginText>20.a/3_A.18.25</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0136-1", "AI05-0184-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The generic package Containers.Bounded{"_"}Multiway{"_"}Trees is new. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Inconsistencies With Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>20.b/5_A.18.25</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<b></b> Tampering with elements is now defined to be equivalent to tampering with cursors for bounded containers. If a program requires tampering detection to work, it might fail in Ada 2022. Needless to say, this shouldn't happen outside of test programs. See Inconsistencies With Ada 2012 in <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.2">A.18.2</a> for more details. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Incompatibilities With Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>20.c/5_A.18.25</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0409-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<b></b>A bounded tree now only has Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization (abbreviated PI in this note) when the actual for the Element{"_"}Type has PI. If an program used a tree whose actual Element{"_"}Type does not have PI in a context when PI is required (such as a library-level object in a preelaborated unit or as a component of a type with PI), the program would be illegal in Ada 2022 but legal in original Ada 2012. This situation is unlikely, especially as some existing Ada 2012 implementations reject the instance in this case. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.26"></a>

## A.18.26  Array Sorting

<MarginText>1/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0001-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic procedures Containers.Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort, Containers.Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort, and Containers.Generic{"_"}Sort provide sorting on arbitrary array types. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>2/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The generic library procedure Containers.Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>3/5_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
generic{"\n"}   type Index{"_"}Type is ({"<"}{">"});{"\n"}   type Element{"_"}Type is private;{"\n"}   type Array{"_"}Type is array (Index{"_"}Type range {"<"}{">"}) of Element{"_"}Type;{"\n"}   with function "{"<"}" (Left, Right : Element{"_"}Type){"\n"}      return Boolean is {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}procedure Ada.Containers.Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort (Container : in out Array{"_"}Type){"\n"}   with Pure, Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>3.a/5_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>Global ={">"} <b>null</b> means that the only global side-effects allowed are associated with the actual generic parameters. Similarly, when Nonblocking is set to True for a generic unit, the only blocking allowed is that associated with the actual generic parameters. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>4/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<p class="Indented4">Reorders the elements of Container such that the elements are sorted smallest first as determined by the generic formal "{"<"}" operator provided. Any exception raised during evaluation of "{"<"}" is propagated.<br /></p>

<MarginText>5/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0044-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">The actual function for the generic formal function "{"<"}" of Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort is expected to return the same value each time it is called with a particular pair of element values. It should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>); it should not modify Container. If the actual for "{"<"}" behaves in some other manner, the behavior of the instance of Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort is unspecified. The number of times Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort calls "{"<"}" is unspecified.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.a/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>This implies swapping the elements, usually including an intermediate copy. This of course means that the elements will be copied. Since the elements are nonlimited, this usually will not be a problem. Note that there is Implementation Advice below that the implementation should use a sort that minimizes copying of elements.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.b/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The sort is not required to be stable (and the fast algorithm required will not be stable). If a stable sort is needed, the user can include the original location of the element as an extra "sort key". We considered requiring the implementation to do that, but it is mostly extra overhead -- usually there is something already in the element that provides the needed stability. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>6/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The generic library procedure Containers.Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>7/5_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
generic{"\n"}   type Index{"_"}Type is ({"<"}{">"});{"\n"}   type Element{"_"}Type is private;{"\n"}   type Array{"_"}Type is array (Index{"_"}Type) of Element{"_"}Type;{"\n"}   with function "{"<"}" (Left, Right : Element{"_"}Type){"\n"}      return Boolean is {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}procedure Ada.Containers.Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort{"\n"}      (Container : in out Array{"_"}Type){"\n"}   with Pure, Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>7.a/5_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>Global ={">"} <b>null</b> means that the only global side-effects allowed are associated with the actual generic parameters. Similarly, when Nonblocking is set to True for a generic unit, the only blocking allowed is that associated with the actual generic parameters. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>8/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<p class="Indented4">Reorders the elements of Container such that the elements are sorted smallest first as determined by the generic formal "{"<"}" operator provided. Any exception raised during evaluation of "{"<"}" is propagated.<br /></p>

<MarginText>9/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0044-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">The actual function for the generic formal function "{"<"}" of Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort is expected to return the same value each time it is called with a particular pair of element values. It should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>); it should not modify Container. If the actual for "{"<"}" behaves in some other manner, the behavior of the instance of Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort is unspecified. The number of times Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort calls "{"<"}" is unspecified.<br /></p>

<MarginText>9.1/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<p>The generic library procedure Containers.Generic{"_"}Sort has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>9.2/5_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0056-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
generic{"\n"}   type Index{"_"}Type is ({"<"}{">"});{"\n"}   with function Before (Left, Right : Index{"_"}Type) return Boolean;{"\n"}   with procedure Swap (Left, Right : in Index{"_"}Type);{"\n"}procedure Ada.Containers.Generic{"_"}Sort{"\n"}      (First, Last : Index{"_"}Type'Base){"\n"}   with Pure, Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>9.a/5_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>Global ={">"} <b>null</b> means that the only global side-effects allowed are associated with the actual generic parameters. Similarly, when Nonblocking is set to True for a generic unit, the only blocking allowed is that associated with the actual generic parameters. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>9.3/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Reorders the elements of an indexable structure, over the range First .. Last, such that the elements are sorted in the ordering determined by the generic formal function Before; Before should return True if Left is to be sorted before Right. The generic formal Before compares the elements having the given indices, and the generic formal Swap exchanges the values of the indicated elements. Any exception raised during evaluation of Before or Swap is propagated.<br /></p>

<MarginText>9.4/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<p class="Indented4">The actual function for the generic formal function Before of Generic{"_"}Sort is expected to return the same value each time it is called with index values that identify a particular pair of element values. It should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>); it should not modify the elements. The actual function for the generic formal Swap should exchange the values of the indicated elements. If the actual for either Before or Swap behaves in some other manner, the behavior of Generic{"_"}Sort is unspecified. The number of times the Generic{"_"}Sort calls Before or Swap is unspecified.<br /></p>


#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>10/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The worst-case time complexity of a call on an instance of Containers.Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort or Containers.Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort should be <i>O</i>(<i>N</i>{"*"}{"*"}2) or better, and the average time complexity should be better than <i>O</i>(<i>N</i>{"*"}{"*"}2), where <i>N</i> is the length of the Container parameter. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>10.a/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<b></b>Containers.Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort and Containers.Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort should have an average time complexity better than <i>O</i>(<i>N</i>{"*"}{"*"}2) and worst case no worse than <i>O</i>(<i>N</i>{"*"}{"*"}2).<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>10.b/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>In other words, we're requiring the use of a sorting algorithm better than <i>O</i>(<i>N</i>{"*"}{"*"}2), such as Quicksort. No bubble sorts allowed! <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>11/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Containers.Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort and Containers.Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort should minimize copying of elements. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>11.a/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<b></b>Containers.Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort and Containers.Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort should minimize copying of elements.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>11.b/2_A.18.26</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<b>To be honest: </b>We do not mean &ldquo;absolutely minimize&rdquo; here; we're not intending to require a single copy for each element. Rather, we want to suggest that the sorting algorithm chosen is one that does not copy items unnecessarily. Bubble sort would not meet this advice, for instance. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>12/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p>The worst-case time complexity of a call on an instance of Containers.Generic{"_"}Sort should be <i>O</i>(<i>N</i>{"*"}{"*"}2) or better, and the average time complexity should be better than <i>O</i>(<i>N</i>{"*"}{"*"}2), where <i>N</i> is the difference between the Last and First parameters plus 1. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.a.1/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<b></b>Containers.Generic{"_"}Sort should have an average time complexity better than <i>O</i>(<i>N</i>{"*"}{"*"}2) and worst case no worse than <i>O</i>(<i>N</i>{"*"}{"*"}2).<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>13/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p>Containers.Generic{"_"}Sort should minimize calls to the generic formal Swap. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>13.a.1/3_A.18.26</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<b></b>Containers.Generic{"_"}Sort should minimize calls to the generic formal Swap.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 95

</AnnotatedOnly>

The generic procedures Containers.Generic{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort and Containers.Generic{"_"}Constrained{"_"}Array{"_"}Sort are new. <br />
</Admonition>

</AnnotatedOnly>

<b></b> Redefined "{"<"}" actuals to require a strict weak ordering; the old definition allowed indeterminant comparisons that would not have worked in a sort. <br />

<a id="Subclause_A.18.27"></a>

## A.18.27  The Generic Package Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces

<MarginText>1/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Synchronized{"_"}Queue{"_"}Interfaces provides interface type Queue, and a set of operations for that type. Interface Queue specifies a first-in, first-out queue. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>2/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The generic library package Containers.Synchronized{"_"}Queue{"_"}Interfaces has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>3/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
generic{"\n"}   type Element{"_"}Type is private;{"\n"}package Ada.Containers.Synchronized{"_"}Queue{"_"}Interfaces{"\n"}   with Pure, Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null is{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>3.a/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>Global ={">"} <b>null</b> means that the only global side-effects allowed are associated with the actual generic parameters. Similarly, when Nonblocking is set to True for a generic unit, the only blocking allowed is that associated with the actual generic parameters. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>4/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   type Queue is synchronized interface;{"\n"}
<MarginText>5/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
   procedure Enqueue{"\n"}     (Container : in out Queue;{"\n"}      New{"_"}Item  : in     Element{"_"}Type) is abstract{"\n"}       with Synchronization ={">"} By{"_"}Entry,{"\n"}           Nonblocking ={">"} False,{"\n"}           Global'Class={">"} in out synchronized;{"\n"}
<MarginText>6/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
   procedure Dequeue{"\n"}     (Container : in out Queue;{"\n"}      Element   :    out Element{"_"}Type) is abstract{"\n"}       with Synchronization ={">"} By{"_"}Entry,{"\n"}           Nonblocking ={">"} False,{"\n"}           Global'Class={">"} in out synchronized;{"\n"}
<MarginText>7/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
   function Current{"_"}Use (Container : Queue) return Count{"_"}Type is abstract{"\n"}       with Nonblocking, Global'Class ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}   function Peak{"_"}Use (Container : Queue) return Count{"_"}Type is abstract{"\n"}       with Nonblocking, Global'Class ={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null,{"\n"}            Post'Class ={">"} Peak{"_"}Use'Result {">"}= Current{"_"}Use (Container);{"\n"}
<MarginText>8/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
end Ada.Containers.Synchronized{"_"}Queue{"_"}Interfaces;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>8.1/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p>The subprogram behavior descriptions given below are the semantics for the corresponding callable entities found in the language-defined generic packages that have a formal package named Queue{"_"}Interfaces.<br /></p>

<MarginText>9/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Enqueue{"\n"}  (Container : in out Queue;{"\n"}   New{"_"}Item  : in     Element{"_"}Type) is abstract{"\n"}   with Synchronization ={">"} By{"_"}Entry{"\n"}        Nonblocking ={">"} False,{"\n"}        Global'Class={">"} in out synchronized;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>10/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0262-1", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">A queue type that implements this interface is allowed to have a bounded <i>capacity</i>. If the queue object has a bounded capacity, and the number of existing elements equals the capacity, then Enqueue blocks until storage becomes available; otherwise, Enqueue does not block. In any case, it then copies New{"_"}Item onto the queue.<br /></p>

<MarginText>11/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Dequeue{"\n"}  (Container : in out Queue;{"\n"}   Element   :    out Element{"_"}Type) is abstract{"\n"}   with Synchronization ={">"} By{"_"}Entry{"\n"}        Nonblocking ={">"} False,{"\n"}        Global'Class={">"} in out synchronized;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>12/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0251-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">If the queue is empty, then Dequeue blocks until an item becomes available. In any case, it then assigns the element at the head of the queue to Element, and removes it from the queue.<br /></p>

<MarginText>13/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Current{"_"}Use (Container : Queue) return Count{"_"}Type is abstract{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global'Class={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>14/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns the number of elements currently in the queue.<br /></p>

<MarginText>15/5_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Peak{"_"}Use (Container : Queue) return Count{"_"}Type is abstract{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global'Class={">"} null, Use{"_"}Formal ={">"} null,{"\n"}         Post'Class ={">"} Peak{"_"}Use'Result {">"}= Current{"_"}Use (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>16/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p class="Indented4">Returns the maximum number of elements that have been in the queue at any one time.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
NOTE   Unlike other language-defined containers, there are no queues whose element types are indefinite. Elements of an indefinite type can be handled by defining the element of the queue to be a holder container (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.18">A.18.18</a>) of the indefinite type, or to be an explicit access type that designates the indefinite type.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.a/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>There are no indefinite queues, as a useful definition for Dequeue is not possible. Dequeue cannot be a function, as Ada does not have entries that are functions (thus conditional and timed calls would not be possible). Moreover, protected functions do not allow modifying the queue object (thus it doesn't work even if we decided we didn't care about conditional and timed calls). If Dequeue is an entry, then the dequeued object would have to be an <b>out</b> parameter and that would require the queue client to guess the tag and constraints of the value that will be dequeued (otherwise Constraint{"_"}Error would be raised), and that is rarely going to be possible. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.b/3_A.18.27</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
 The generic package Containers.Synchronized{"_"}Queue{"_"}Interfaces is new. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.28"></a>

## A.18.28  The Generic Package Containers.Unbounded_Synchronized_Queues


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>1/3_A.18.28</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Unbounded{"_"}Synchronized{"_"}Queues provides type Queue, which implements the interface type Containers.Synchronized{"_"}Queue{"_"}Interfaces.Queue.<br /></p>

<MarginText>2/5_A.18.28</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
with System;{"\n"}with Ada.Containers.Synchronized{"_"}Queue{"_"}Interfaces;{"\n"}generic{"\n"}   with package Queue{"_"}Interfaces is{"\n"}      new Ada.Containers.Synchronized{"_"}Queue{"_"}Interfaces ({"<"}{">"});{"\n"}   Default{"_"}Ceiling : System.Any{"_"}Priority := System.Priority'Last;{"\n"}package Ada.Containers.Unbounded{"_"}Synchronized{"_"}Queues{"\n"}   with Preelaborate,{"\n"}        Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in out synchronized is{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>2.a/5_A.18.28</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<b></b>For discussion on the reasons and meaning of the specifications of the Global and Nonblocking aspects of this generic package, see the notes on the specification of the Containers.Vectors package (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.2">A.18.2</a>). <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>3/3_A.18.28</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   package Implementation is{"\n"}      ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}   end Implementation;{"\n"}
<MarginText>4/3_A.18.28</MarginText>

This nested package is necessary as types cannot be declared in the private part of a protected type, and the types have to be declared within the generic unit in order to depend on the types imported with package Queue{"_"}Interfaces. Clients should never depend on the contents of nested package Implementation. <br />
</Admonition>

<MarginText>12/3_A.18.30</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The type Queue is used to represent task-safe priority queues.<br /></p>

<MarginText>13/3_A.18.30</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The capacity for instances of type Queue is unbounded.<br /></p>

<MarginText>14/3_A.18.30</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>Two elements <i>E1</i> and <i>E2</i> are equivalent if Before(Get{"_"}Priority(<i>E1</i>), Get{"_"}Priority(<i>E2</i>)) and Before(Get{"_"}Priority(<i>E2</i>), Get{"_"}Priority(<i>E1</i>)) both return False.<br /></p>

<MarginText>15/3_A.18.30</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p>The actual functions for Get{"_"}Priority and Before are expected to return the same value each time they are called with the same actuals, and should not modify their actuals. Before should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>). If the actual functions behave in some other manner, the behavior of Unbounded{"_"}Priority{"_"}Queues is unspecified.<br /></p>

<MarginText>16/3_A.18.30</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>Enqueue inserts an item according to the order specified by the Before function on the result of Get{"_"}Priority on the elements; Before should return True if Left is to be inserted before Right. If the queue already contains elements equivalent to New{"_"}Item, then it is inserted after the existing equivalent elements.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>16.a/3_A.18.30</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>Enqueue never blocks; if more storage is needed for a new element, it is allocated dynamically. We don't need to explicitly specify that Queue needs finalization, because it is visibly protected. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>17/3_A.18.30</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0251-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>For a call on Dequeue{"_"}Only{"_"}High{"_"}Priority, if the head of the nonempty queue is <i>E</i>, and the function Before(At{"_"}Least, Get{"_"}Priority(<i>E</i>)) returns False, then <i>E</i> is assigned to Element and then removed from the queue, and Success is set to True; otherwise, Success is set to False and Element is unchanged.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.a/3_A.18.30</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<b></b>Unlike Dequeue, Dequeue{"_"}Only{"_"}High{"_"}Priority is not blocking; it always returns immediately. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.b/3_A.18.30</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>The use of Before is "backwards" so that it acts like "{">"}=" (it is defined similarly to "{">"}"); thus we dequeue only when it is False. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

## A.18.32  The Generic Package Containers.Bounded_Indefinite_Holders

<MarginText>1/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Bounded{"_"}Indefinite{"_"}Holders provides a private type Holder and a set of operations for that type. It provides the same operations as the package Containers.Indefinite{"_"}Holders (see <a href="/docs/arm/AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.18">A.18.18</a>), with the difference that the maximum storage is bounded. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>2/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>The declaration of the generic library package Containers.Bounded{"_"}Indefinite{"_"}Holders has the same contents and semantics as Containers.Indefinite{"_"}Holders except:<br /></p>

<MarginText>3/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>The following is added to the context clause:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>4/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   with System.Storage{"_"}Elements; use System.Storage{"_"}Elements;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>5/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>An additional generic parameter follows Element{"_"}Type:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>6/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   Max{"_"}Element{"_"}Size{"_"}in{"_"}Storage{"_"}Elements : Storage{"_"}Count;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>6.a/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>This value is in Storage{"_"}Elements so that it can be used as a discriminant on a storage pool object in the implementation of the object; Ada doesn't allow discriminant dependent components to use formulas.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>6.b/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
This is a generic parameter as it is a property of the Element{"_"}Type; the largest possible object of Element{"_"}Type is unlikely to be different for different containers, so making it a discriminant (as Capacity is) provides no useful capability. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>7/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0409-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>The <code><a href="/docs/arm/AA-13/AA-13.1#S0348">aspect_definition</a></code> for Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization for type Holder is changed to: <br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>8/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization ={">"}{"\n"}     Element{"_"}Type'Preelaborable{"_"}Initialization{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>9/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>Add to the precondition of To{"_"}Holder and Replace{"_"}Element:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>10/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  and then (New{"_"}Item'Size {"<"}={"\n"}               Max{"_"}Element{"_"}Size{"_"}in{"_"}Storage{"_"}Elements {"*"} System.Storage{"_"}Unit{"\n"}            or else raise Program{"_"}Error){"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>10.a/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>This ensures that an object that won't fit is not inserted into the container. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Bounded (Run-Time) Errors

<MarginText>11/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>It is a bounded error to assign from a bounded holder object while tampering with elements of that object is prohibited. Either Program{"_"}Error is raised by the assignment, execution proceeds with the target object prohibiting tampering with elements, or execution proceeds normally. <br /></p>


#### Implementation Requirements

<MarginText>12/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>For each instance of Containers.Indefinite{"_"}Holders and each instance of Containers.Bounded{"_"}Indefinite{"_"}Holders, if the two instances meet the following conditions, then the output generated by the Holder'Output or Holder'Write subprograms of either instance shall be readable by the Holder'Input or Holder'Read of the other instance, respectively:<br /></p>

<MarginText>13/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>the Element{"_"}Type parameters of the two instances are statically matching subtypes of the same type; and<br /></li>
<MarginText>14/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<li>the output generated by Element{"_"}Type'Output or Element{"_"}Type'Write is readable by Element{"_"}Type'Input or Element{"_"}Type'Read, respectively (where Element{"_"}Type denotes the type of the two actual Element{"_"}Type parameters). <br /></li>
</ul>

#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>15/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>Bounded holder objects should be implemented without dynamic allocation and any finalization should be trivial unless Element{"_"}Type needs finalization. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>15.a.1/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<b></b>Bounded holder objects should be implemented without dynamic allocation.<br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>15.a/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<b>To be honest: </b>Implementation of this container in Ada will probably require the use of a special storage pool. When we say "without dynamic allocation", we mean that this pool does not use heap memory and has a trivial finalization routine (that is, procedures Adjust and Finalize are null procedures). All storage pools are controlled, so we can't reasonably say that a bounded holder will not need finalization. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>15.b/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<b></b>If the implementation supports discontiguous objects that require multiple calls to Allocate in a storage pool, the storage pool will need to support such allocations. The storage pool implementation can assume that all Allocate calls occur together, and similarly for Deallocate calls, thus simplifying the pool implementation so that allocation only occurs at a high-water mark location. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>16/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0350-1", "AI12-0445-1"]} />
<p>The  about the Move and Swap operations is deleted for bounded holders; these operations can copy elements as necessary.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>16.a/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<b></b>The memory of a bounded indefinite holder belongs directly to the container, so it cannot be moved with the element. If the element type contains any internal pointers, moving it without calling Adjust would leave such pointers pointing to the wrong holder object. Thus, a full copy is needed, including any associated finalization and adjustments. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>16.b/5_A.18.32</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
 The generic package Containers.Bounded{"_"}Indefinite{"_"}Holders is new. <br />
</Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.33"></a>

## A.18.33  Example of Container Use


#### Examples

<MarginText>1/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>The following example is an implementation of Dijkstra's shortest path algorithm in a directed graph with positive distances. The graph is represented by a map from nodes to sets of edges.<br /></p>

<MarginText>2/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
with Ada.Containers.Vectors;{"\n"}with Ada.Containers.Doubly{"_"}Linked{"_"}Lists;{"\n"}use Ada.Containers;{"\n"}generic{"\n"}   type Node is range {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}package Shortest{"_"}Paths is{"\n"}   type Distance is new Float range 0.0 .. Float'Last;{"\n"}   type Edge is record{"\n"}      To, From : Node;{"\n"}      Length   : Distance;{"\n"}   end record;{"\n"}
<MarginText>3/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
   package Node{"_"}Maps is new Vectors (Node, Node);{"\n"}   -- The algorithm builds a map to indicate the node used to reach a given{"\n"}   -- node in the shortest distance.{"\n"}
<MarginText>4/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
   package Adjacency{"_"}Lists is new Doubly{"_"}Linked{"_"}Lists (Edge);{"\n"}   use Adjacency{"_"}Lists;{"\n"}
<MarginText>5/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
   package Graphs is new Vectors (Node, Adjacency{"_"}Lists.List);{"\n"}
<MarginText>6/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
   package Paths is new Doubly{"_"}Linked{"_"}Lists (Node);{"\n"}
<MarginText>7/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
   function Shortest{"_"}Path{"\n"}     (G : Graphs.Vector; Source : Node; Target : Node) return Paths.List{"\n"}      with Pre ={">"} G (Source) /= Adjacency{"_"}Lists.Empty{"_"}List;{"\n"}
<MarginText>8/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
end Shortest{"_"}Paths;{"\n"}
<MarginText>9/5_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0178-1"]} />
package body Shortest{"_"}Paths is{"\n"}   function Shortest{"_"}Path{"\n"}     (G : Graphs.Vector; Source : Node; Target : Node) return Paths.List{"\n"}   is{"\n"}      use Node{"_"}Maps, Paths, Graphs;{"\n"}      Reached  : array (Node) of Boolean := (others ={">"} False);{"\n"}      -- The set of nodes whose shortest distance to the source is known.{"\n"}
<MarginText>10/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0299-1"]} />
      Reached{"_"}From : array (Node) of Node;{"\n"}      So{"_"}Far   : array (Node) of Distance := (others ={">"} Distance'Last);{"\n"}      The{"_"}Path : Paths.List := Paths.Empty{"_"}List;{"\n"}      Nearest{"_"}Distance : Distance;{"\n"}      Next     : Node;{"\n"}   begin{"\n"}      So{"_"}Far(Source)  := 0.0;{"\n"}
<MarginText>11/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
      while not Reached(Target) loop{"\n"}         Nearest{"_"}Distance := Distance'Last;{"\n"}
<MarginText>12/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
         -- Find closest node not reached yet, by iterating over all nodes.{"\n"}         -- A more efficient algorithm uses a priority queue for this step.{"\n"}
<MarginText>13/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
         Next := Source;{"\n"}         for N in Node'First .. Node'Last loop{"\n"}            if not Reached(N){"\n"}              and then So{"_"}Far(N) {"<"} Nearest{"_"}Distance then{"\n"}                 Next := N;{"\n"}                 Nearest{"_"}Distance := So{"_"}Far(N);{"\n"}            end if;{"\n"}         end loop;{"\n"}
<MarginText>14/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0299-1"]} />
         if Nearest{"_"}Distance = Distance'Last then{"\n"}            -- No next node found, graph is not connected{"\n"}            return Paths.Empty{"_"}List;{"\n"}
<MarginText>15/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
         else{"\n"}            Reached(Next) := True;{"\n"}         end if;{"\n"}
<MarginText>16/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
         -- Update minimum distance to newly reachable nodes.{"\n"}
<MarginText>17/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0299-1"]} />
         for E of G (Next) loop{"\n"}            if not Reached(E.To) then{"\n"}               Nearest{"_"}Distance := E.Length + So{"_"}Far(Next);{"\n"}
<MarginText>18/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
               if Nearest{"_"}Distance {"<"} So{"_"}Far(E.To) then{"\n"}                  Reached{"_"}From(E.To) := Next;{"\n"}                  So{"_"}Far(E.To) := Nearest{"_"}Distance;{"\n"}               end if;{"\n"}            end if;{"\n"}         end loop;{"\n"}      end loop;{"\n"}
<MarginText>19/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
      -- Rebuild path from target to source.{"\n"}
<MarginText>20/5_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0386-1"]} />
      declare{"\n"}         N : Node := Target;{"\n"}      begin{"\n"}         Prepend (The{"_"}Path, N);{"\n"}         while N /= Source loop{"\n"}            N := Reached{"_"}From(N);{"\n"}            Prepend (The{"_"}Path, N);{"\n"}         end loop;{"\n"}      end;{"\n"}
<MarginText>21/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
      return The{"_"}Path;{"\n"}   end;{"\n"}end Shortest{"_"}Paths;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>22/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>Note that the effect of the Constant{"_"}Indexing aspect (on type Vector) and the Implicit{"_"}Dereference aspect (on type Reference{"_"}Type) is that<br /></p>

<MarginText>23/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
G (Next){"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>24/5_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1", "AI12-0426-1"]} />
<p>is a convenient shorthand for<br /></p>

<MarginText>25/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
G.Constant{"_"}Reference (Next).Element.all{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>26/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>Similarly, the effect of the loop:<br /></p>

<MarginText>27/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
for E of G (Next) loop{"\n"}   if not Reached(E.To) then{"\n"}      ...{"\n"}   end if;{"\n"}end loop;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>28/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>is the same as:<br /></p>

<MarginText>29/4_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0080-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
for C in G (Next).Iterate loop{"\n"}   declare{"\n"}      E : Edge renames G (Next)(C);{"\n"}   begin{"\n"}      if not Reached(E.To) then{"\n"}         ...{"\n"}      end if;{"\n"}   end;{"\n"}end loop;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>30/3_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>which is the same as:<br /></p>

<MarginText>31/4_A.18.33</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0080-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
declare{"\n"}   L : Adjacency{"_"}Lists.List renames G (Next);{"\n"}   C : Adjacency{"_"}Lists.Cursor := L.First;{"\n"}begin{"\n"}   while Has{"_"}Element (C) loop{"\n"}      declare{"\n"}         E : Edge renames L(C);{"\n"}      begin{"\n"}         if not Reached(E.To) then{"\n"}            ...{"\n"}         end if;{"\n"}      end;{"\n"}      C := L.Next (C);{"\n"}   end loop;{"\n"}end;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
